qas.question: What kind of wires does the USB 2.0 variant use?
What are the four shielded wires in the USB 2.0 variant used for?

answers.text: two for power (VBUS and GND), and two for differential data signals

context: USB is <a0_0>a serial bus<a0_0/>, using <a1_0>four shielded wires<a1_0/> for the USB 2.0 variant: <a2_0>two for power (VBUS and GND), and two for differential data signals<a2_0/> (labelled as D+ and D− in pinouts). Non-Return-to-Zero Inverted (NRZI) encoding scheme is used for transferring data, with a sync field to synchronize the host and receiver clocks. D+ and D− signals are transmitted on a twisted pair, providing half-duplex data transfers for USB 2.0. Mini and micro connectors have their GND connections moved from pin #4 to pin #5, while their pin #4 serves as an ID pin for the On-The-Go host/client identification.
